Company M, [[16th Regiment Illinois Volunteer Cavalry|16th Illinois Volunteer Cavalry]] |commands= |battles= [[American Civil War]] |awards= |laterwork= [[Railway Mail Service]] (chief clerk), politician, [[List of Grand Army of the Republic Commanders-in-Chief|11th Commander-in-Chief]] of the [[Grand Army of the Republic]], land speculator }} '''Paul Vandervoort''' (July 12, 1846 – July 29, 1902) was an [[United States|American]] soldier who served in the [[Union Army]] and as the [[List of Grand Army of the Republic Commanders-in-Chief|11th Commander-in-Chief]] of the [[Grand Army of the Republic]], 1882-1883. ==Early life and military career== Vandervoort was born July 12, 1846 in [[Clinton County, Ohio|Clinton County]], [[Ohio]] to William and Theresa (Harvey) Vandervoort. During the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], he lied about his age and enlisted June 10, 1862 as a private in Company G, [[68th Illinois Volunteer Infantry Regiment|68th Illinois Volunteer Infantry]] (a 3-month regiment). Vandervoort was mustered out September 26, 1862 at Camp Butler near [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]], [[Illinois]]. On May 19, 1863 he enlisted as a private in Company M, [[16th Regiment Illinois Volunteer Cavalry|16th Illinois Volunteer Cavalry]] (again, lying about his age) and mustered out of the service August 1, 1865 as a [[Sergeant#American_Civil_War|sergeant]]. While with the 16th Illinois Cavalry, Vandervoort was captured by Confederates near [[Jonesville, Virginia|Jonesville]], [[Virginia]] in December 1863 and held at [[Andersonville National Historic Site|Andersonville]], [[Belle Isle (Richmond, Virginia)|Belle Isle]], and [[Libby Prison|Libby]] prisons. ==Post-war service== Following the Civil War, Vandervoort became active in politics, first in Illinois and later in [[Omaha]], [[Nebraska]], where he also worked as chief clerk for the [[Railway Mail Service]]. Like many other Union Army veterans, Vandervoort was a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]; however, he later switched his political affiliation to the [[People's Party (United States)|Populist Party]]. Vandervoort became active in the Grand Army of the Republic in 1866 and helped reorganize the Department of Nebraska after the organizations' initial difficulties. He was elected 11th Commander-in-Chief of the G.A.R. and served 1882-1883. Of particular note is that Vandervoort was the first veteran who had been an enlisted man to rise to the highest position within the G.A.R.. At the 1883 National Encampment, the National Woman's Relief Corps was recognized as an official auxiliary organization of the G.A.R. and Vandervoort was made an honorary member. When Vandervoort lost his position with the Railway Mail Service, he became an assistant manager for the Cuban Land and Steamship Company of New York. Vandervoort helped transport many Union Army veterans who hoped to find new lives as citrus farmers in [[Cuba]] after the United States installed a government there in 1899. Vandervoort became a land speculator and personally laid out a colony known as La Gloria, which became the largest American settlement in Cuba. Vandervoort did not live to see La Gloria prosper. He died July 29, 1902 in [[Camagüey|Puerto Principe]], Cuba and is buried at [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Omaha)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]] in Omaha. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United States Army|American Civil War}} *[[List of Grand Army of the Republic Commanders-in-Chief]] ==References== * Grand Army of the Republic.
